questions.text: A 19-year-old man is brought by ambulance to the emergency department for altered mental status and seizure activity. He had been drinking alcohol with his friends for the past several hours when they realized he was absent from the house. He was found prone in the backyard, surrounded by emesis, and unresponsive to voice and tactile stimulation. He developed diffuse tonic extension of the limbs and rhythmic jerking that has persisted upon arrival despite administration of two doses of intravenous lorazepam. A finger-stick glucose is normal. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, blood pressure is 120/80, and oxygen saturation is 85% on room air. On exam, bilateral eyes are open and deviated upwards. He does not respond to verbal commands nor painful stimuli. Pulmonary exam reveals decreased breath sounds and crackles throughout. Bilateral upper extremities are flexed, and his bilateral lower extremities are extended with rhythmic jerking in both the upper and lower extremities. A bolus of levetiracetam is infused. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the direct cause of this patient’s seizure activity?

choices.text: Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) without contrast
Computerized tomography (CT) of the head with contrast

questions.solution:
This patient is in convulsive status epilepticus based on the presence of a tonic-clonic seizure lasting longer than five minutes. For patients found down with evidence of hypoxia, neuroimaging is indicated to investigate for anoxic brain injury as the cause for seizure. A brain MRI without contrast may show a global loss of gray-white matter differentiation and cerebral edema.       

Patients with alcohol intoxication or poisoning who lose consciousness are at risk of choking on their vomit and potentially dying from asphyxiation. Anoxic brain injury can lead to seizure activity in these patients.       

The differential diagnosis for an adult presenting in convulsive status epilepticus includes a subtherapeutic level of an antiseizure medication for those with epilepsy, substance intoxication or withdrawal, acute metabolic derangements, infection, autoimmunity, trauma, ischemia, hemorrhage, or hypoxia. First-line diagnostic tests include a finger-stick glucose, an antiseizure medication level if appropriate, a toxicology screen, an ethanol level, and a comprehensive metabolic profile. Second-line investigations include a complete blood count, cerebrospinal fluid analysis, and neuroimaging. MRI provides the most detailed image without exposure to radiation.       

Option Analysis

✅ Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) without contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head with contrast:
Incorrect: A head CT without contrast can sometimes confirm evidence of a hypoxic/anoxic brain injury or investigate for trauma signs, but a brain MRI is more detailed and does not carry the associated radiation exposure risk. CT imaging with contrast imaging is helpful for evaluating vascular causes like aneurysms. 
❌ Electroencephalography (EEG):
Incorrect: EEG monitoring can differentiate between epileptic or nonepileptic seizures, evaluate for response to medication, and rule out nonconvulsive seizures; but it does not identify the underlying cause for the seizure. Neuroimaging with MRI in this case is more helpful in determining the etiology for seizure.  
❌ Chest radiography:
Incorrect: Chest radiography can reveal signs of an aspiration pneumonia in an asphyxiation by emesis event, but neuroimaging investigates for evidence of associated hypoxia/anoxia resulting in seizure. 
❌ Urine toxicology screen:
Incorrect: A urine toxicology screen could investigate for intoxication, but this patient is hypoxic, hypopneic, and convulsing with a history of a likely asphyxiation event; these findings are concerning for an anoxic brain injury, which could be confirmed by neuroimaging. Urine toxicology could reveal the cause of intoxication, but brain imaging is necessary to diagnose anoxic brain injury that causes seizures.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for follow-up of epilepsy. For the past few years, she has been managed for unprovoked recurrent brief episodes of feeling a tingling sensation in her left hand and forearm. The symptoms last 30-45 seconds and are not associated with position or postictal status. There is no numbness or weakness. She occasionally has accompanying stiffness of the arm. The episodes have been well-controlled with carbamazepine. Past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus for which she takes metformin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. On exam, sensation, strength, and reflexes are normal in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. The rest of the neurologic examination is non-focal. Which of the following is most likely to reveal the underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is being treated for epilepsy, defined as at least 2 unprovoked seizures separated by at least 24 hours, and the description of her symptoms as paresthesia and stiffening of one arm indicates a diagnosis of focal seizures. Patients with focal epilepsy may experience convulsions of one part of the body as opposed to generalized tonic-clonic seizures. They may experience paresthesias in one part of the body or see flashing lights or have other visual symptoms. While the underlying cause of epilepsy is often unknown, many cases of focal epilepsy are caused by structural abnormalities. A focused history may reveal a remote history of head trauma, central nervous system (CNS) infection, stroke, congenital malformation, or degenerative CNS condition. There may also be a family history of epilepsy indicating genetic etiology.        

Structural etiology is more likely in patients with focal epilepsy as opposed to those with generalized epilepsy. The description of the focal seizure may suggest the anatomic region of the brain affected. For example, focal paresthesia, as described in this patient, may localize to the contralateral somatosensory cortex, while focal motor activity may localize to the contralateral motor cortex. Déjà vu, fear or anxiety, an abnormal smell or taste, or automatisms suggest a temporal lobe focus. Visual hallucinations or seeing flashing lights are common with occipital lobe seizures.    

Option Analysis

✅ Trauma history:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Birth and developmental history:
Incorrect: In pediatric patients, a birth and developmental history may reveal an underlying contributing factor for the development of epilepsy. However, adults are more likely to have had a recent history of head trauma leading to new seizure activity especially in patients like this one with focal seizures. 
❌ Substance use history:
Incorrect: Both use and withdrawal from recreational substances can be secondary causes of provoked seizures (e.g. alcohol); however, this patient is diagnosed with epilepsy, which refers to repeated, unprovoked seizures. In adult patients with epilepsy, especially with focal seizures, there is likely to be a family history of epilepsy, personal history of head trauma, or other causes of a focal structural lesion. 
❌ Hemoglobin A1c level:
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia and other metabolic derangements can be secondary causes of provoked seizures; however, this patient with repeated unprovoked episodes (i.e. epilepsy) is more likely to have a family history of epilepsy, a personal history of head trauma, or other cause for a focal structural lesion. 
❌ Menstrual history:
Incorrect: Some women can experience catamenial epilepsy, where seizures are worsened during certain phases of the menstrual cycle in response to hormonal changes throughout the cycle. However, this 60-year-old woman would be expected to be postmenopausal and more likely has a history of head trauma that led to focal seizures.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of recurrent episodes of déjà vu. Several times over the past 3 weeks, he has experienced a feeling of having already experienced a situation, accompanied by anxiety, lasting about 30-45 seconds. He notes an unpleasant odor or metallic taste just prior to these episodes. Afterward, he feels slightly drowsy. Past medical history includes hypertension for which he takes lisinopril. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 124/86 mmHg. Vision and hearing exams are normal. Neurological examination, including a fundoscopic exam, is normal. Which of the following should be performed next to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms consistent with focal epilepsy stemming from the temporal lobe. The workup for an adult with seizures and suspected epilepsy includes an electroencephalogram to diagnose seizure activity and determine the seizure type. This should be followed with neuroimaging with either computerized tomography or magnetic resonance imaging of the brain. 30-40% of epilepsy syndromes are genetically mediated, and genetic testing is also recommended, especially if there is a family history of epilepsy.        

Electrographically, generalized seizures feature bilateral and simultaneous abnormal electrical activity, whereas focal seizures demonstrate abnormal electrical activity in one specific region of the brain. This patient's symptoms suggest a temporal lobe origin. Neuroimaging in patients with focal seizures may reveal the underlying etiology, such as focal gliosis from a remote trauma, infection, or stroke, a cortical dysplasia or other malformation, a neurocutaneous condition like neurofibromatosis or tuberous sclerosis, or a degenerative condition like prion disease. Temporal lobe seizures can also arise from mesial temporal sclerosis. When the diagnostic testing does not yield a formal diagnosis, but the clinical history is suggestive of epilepsy, empiric response to antiseizure medication can be used to confirm the diagnosis.   

Option Analysis

✅ Electroencephalography:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain:
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms concerning for seizures, which can be confirmed through electroencephalography (EEG). Seizures may be the result of structural abnormalities of the brain for which an MRI could be helpful, but an EEG should be performed first to diagnose seizure activity. 
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head :
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms concerning for seizures, which can be confirmed through electroencephalography (EEG). While seizures may be the result of structural abnormalities of the brain for which a head CT could be helpful, an EEG should be performed first to make the diagnosis. 
❌ Carotid ultrasound:
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms concerning for seizures, which can be confirmed with electroencephalography (EEG). Seizures can occur secondary to transient ischemic attacks from carotid insufficiency; however, an EEG should be performed first. 
❌ Overnight polysomnography:
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms concerning for seizures, which can be confirmed with electroencephalography (EEG). An overnight polysomnogram can be helpful for patients with daytime drowsiness or memory concerns but only includes a few EEG electrodes which cannot fully diagnose seizures.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department following a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. His past medical history is significant for nephrotic syndrome due to membranous glomerulopathy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Bloodwork reveals a normal creatinine clearance. The physician decides to start the patient on phenytoin with one loading dose followed by a maintenance dose. Which of the following alterations should be made to the dosing given this patient’s underlying nephrotic syndrome?

choices.text: Lower loading dose and maintenance dose

questions.solution:
Volume of distribution refers to a theoretical volume that denotes how much space a medication (“drug”) occupies in the body. Small volumes of distribution (e.g., 3 liters) signify a medication that is mostly or exclusively found in plasma. Large volumes of distribution (e.g., 60 liters) signify a medication that is found throughout the body. Although each medication has a set volume of distribution, altered physiology can change this value. Diseases such as cirrhosis and nephrotic syndrome can increase the volume of distribution of medication, requiring a higher dose to achieve the same effect. In contrast, pathologic states such as severe dehydration can reduce the volume of distribution.  

Maintenance doses are affected by the underlying renal or hepatic function. With renal or hepatic impairment,  medications are not cleared as quickly, so lower doses are administered to achieve the same results. Impaired medication clearance is incredibly important in clinical practice, as certain medications can become toxic quickly if the dose is not reduced in patients with impaired clearance (e.g., morphine and renal clearance).  

Option Analysis

✅ Higher loading dose:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lower loading dose:
Incorrect: Since the volume of distribution is elevated in nephrotic syndrome, a higher loading dose for medications is generally required.
❌ Higher maintenance dose:
Incorrect: Higher maintenance doses may be required in patients who previously had impaired kidney or liver function, with subsequent improvement. There is no indication that this patient requires higher maintenance doses.
❌ Lower maintenance dose:
Incorrect: Lower maintenance doses may be required in patients with impaired clearance (either via the kidney or liver). There is no indication that this patient has renal or hepatic impairment, so clearance should not be affected.
❌ Lower loading dose and maintenance dose:
Incorrect: A lower loading dose may be required in a patient with a smaller volume of distribution (e.g., severe dehydration). A lower maintenance dose may be required in patients with impaired renal or hepatic function.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department in status epilepticus. Per emergency medical services, the patient was wandering the streets aimlessly when a bystander saw him fall to the ground and shake uncontrollably. Past medical history is unknown. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 111/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 105/65 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 93% on room air. Physical examination reveals a disheveled male with uncontrolled tremors in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. The patient is given a medication that works by increasing the rate of chloride channel opening via agonism of the GABAA receptor. Which of the following medications was most likely used in the treatment of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with status epilepticus is administered a medication that increases the rate of chloride channel opening via allosteric modulation of the GABAA receptor. This description is most consistent with the mechanism of action of benzodiazepines. Of the medications listed, only lorazepam falls into this medication class.  

Both benzodiazepines and barbiturates act on the GABAA receptor and affect chloride-selective ion channels. These effects lead to neuronal hyperpolarization and decreased excitability. Therefore, these medications are excellent for acute seizure control.    

However, benzodiazepines and barbiturates differ in their specific mechanisms of action. Benzodiazepines facilitate GABAA activity by increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening, whereas barbiturates work by increasing the duration of chloride channel opening.  

Ultimately, this mechanistic difference accounts for a “gating effect” with benzodiazepines, such that only a certain amount of GABA can be released upon medication binding. In contrast, with barbiturate use, the chloride channel is in an open state while the medication exerts its effects. As a result, barbiturates are associated with uninhibited GABA release, which can manifest as more profound sedative effects and increased toxicity in overdose when compared to benzodiazepines. 

Option Analysis

✅ Lorazepam:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Phenobarbital:
Incorrect: Phenobarbital, a barbiturate, can be used in the treatment of status epilepticus. However, the mechanism of action of barbiturates is slightly different than that of benzodiazepines. This class of medication works by binding to GABAA receptors and increasing the duration of chloride channel opening.
❌ Thiopental :
 Incorrect: Thiopental is a barbiturate that works by increasing the duration, not the frequency, of chloride channel opening.  
❌ Levetiracetam :
Incorrect: Levetiracetam is an anti-epileptic medication that has an unclear mechanism of action but is thought to modulate GABA and glutamate release as well as inhibit voltage-gated Ca2+  channels. 
❌ Phenytoin :
Incorrect: Phenytoin is an anti-epileptic medication that works via sodium channel blockade. It does not act on the GABA receptors.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to his neurologist for a routine follow-up. For the past six months, the patient occasionally smells “burnt rubber,” followed by a motionless stare where the patient becomes unresponsive. Non-contrast head CT performed at follow-up one month ago was within normal limits. The patient was diagnosed with medial temporal lobe epilepsy and prescribed carbamazepine. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with medial temporal lobe epilepsy–a focal seizure disorder originating from the medial temporal lobe. Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant frequently used in focal epilepsy treatment and generalized tonic-clonic seizures.    

Carbamazepine works by inhibiting voltage-gated sodium channels. Ultimately, this effect inhibits the generation of action potentials and release of excitatory neurotransmitters inhibiting seizure activity.    

Other anticonvulsants that also work via inhibiting the voltage-gated sodium channels include valproic acid, phenytoin, topiramate, and lamotrigine. Some of these medications exert additional effects that contribute to their anticonvulsant properties.  



Option Analysis

✅ Inhibition of voltage-gated sodium channels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ GABA-A receptor agonist :
Incorrect: Benzodiazepines and barbiturates are GABA analogs that directly stimulate GABA-A receptors. 
❌ Inhibition of GABA reuptake :
Incorrect: Tiagabine is an anticonvulsant that works via inhibiting GABA reuptake. Benzodiazepines do not inhibit GABA reuptake.
❌ Inhibition of GABA breakdown :
Incorrect: GABA transaminase is the enzyme responsible for breaking down GABA, which is inhibited by anticonvulsants like valproate and vigabatrin. 
❌  Inhibition of voltage-gated calcium channels:
Incorrect: Carbamazepine as an anticonvulsant inhibits voltage-gated sodium channels, not voltage-gated calcium channels.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician for routine follow-up. The patient was diagnosed with complex temporal lobe seizures associated with impaired consciousness one year ago. A brain MRI was performed at that time and was unrevealing. She has been taking carbamazepine since then but continues to have breakthrough seizures. The physician changes the patient to a medication that works by inhibiting the brain's breakdown of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA). Which of the following is the most likely medication used in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a poorly controlled seizure disorder and is initiated on a medication that inhibits the breakdown of GABA. Of the choices listed, only vigabatrin is known to carry this mechanism of action.    

GABA serves as the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain. When released in the nerve terminals, it binds to the GABA-A receptors in postsynaptic membranes, opening chloride channels, and allowing negatively charged chloride to enter the cell. This results in hyperpolarization of the postsynaptic membrane, thus inhibiting action potential generation. GABA is then taken up by adjacent neurons and broken down by the enzyme GABA transaminase.    

Certain anti-epileptic medications exert their effect by increasing the concentration of GABA in nerve terminals, which inhibits neuronal excitation and subsequent seizure activity.
   
  •  Tiagabine is a GABA reuptake inhibitor that blocks the channels responsible for GABA reuptake, thus increasing the concentration of GABA in the synaptic cleft.  
  •  Vigabatrin and valproic acid are two antiepileptics that inhibit GABA transaminase, thus enhancing the effects of inhibitory neurons.  


Option Analysis

✅ Vigabatrin :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Phenobarbital :
Incorrect: Phenobarbital binds to GABA-A receptors and inhibits action potential generation in the central nervous system. This medication does not inhibit the breakdown of GABA. 
❌ Phenytoin :
Incorrect: Phenytoin inhibits voltage-gated sodium channels and the propagation of action potentials in nerve terminals. It exerts no effect on the metabolism of GABA. 
❌ Gabapentin :
Incorrect: Gabapentin acts as a GABA analog that works by inhibiting voltage-gated calcium channels. It exerts no effect on GABA metabolism. 
❌ Lamotrigine :
Incorrect:  Lamotrigine inhibits voltage-gated sodium channels and glutamate release. It does not affect GABA metabolism.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of involuntary movements. For the past several years, she has experienced occasional involuntary jerking movements of her arms, particularly in the morning, and she has been told by teachers that she is often daydreaming. Since starting college 3 months ago, she has not been sleeping regularly and has noticed more episodes of involuntary movements. With these episodes of movements, she does not have a premonitory urge or sense of relief after the movements. She has no pertinent past medical history and takes no medication. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has juvenile myoclonic epilepsy, which is a common generalized subtype of epilepsy in adolescents. It is a lifelong condition, with seizures continuing into adulthood. It is characterized by early morning myoclonic jerks, with myoclonic jerks worsened by sleep deprivation. There may also be features of other types of generalized seizures including tonic-clonic seizures and absence seizures. The electroencephalographic signature shows 4-6 Hz generalized polyspike and slow wave discharges.        

Generalized seizures may feature a tonic (stiffening) or clonic (jerking) component or a combination of the two (e.g. tonic-clonic). Other generalized seizure subtypes include atonic (loss of tone), absence, and myoclonic seizures, which can be determined by seizure description along with electroencephalography capturing a typical episode. Generalized seizures feature bilateral and simultaneous abnormal electrical activity, whereas focal seizures show abnormal electrical activity in one specific region of the brain.   

Option Analysis

✅ Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder:
Incorrect: Attention deficit disorder can cause inattention; however, it is not characterized by abnormal motor movements. This patient’s early morning jerking movements and increase in jerking movements when she is sleep-deprived are concerning for myoclonic seizures. Additionally, episodes of daydreaming may be from the absence of seizures. 
❌ Childhood absence epilepsy:
Incorrect: Childhood absence of epilepsy can present as staring spells in childhood. It is only rarely associated with jerking movements of the muscles, and it usually remits by adolescence.
❌ Alcohol withdrawal:
Incorrect: Alcohol withdrawal can cause tremors but not usually myoclonus. This patient’s myoclonic jerks and staring spells are concerning for generalized epilepsy, specifically juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. 
❌ Tic disorder:
Incorrect: Tics are accompanied by a premonitory urge and sense of relief after the tic, that typically occurs throughout the day. However, this patient with daydreaming spells and early morning jerks worsened with sleep deprivation are concerning for juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician to evaluate the recurrent loss of consciousness. His partner tells the physician that he has suffered multiple episodes where he suddenly falls to the floor, shaking uncontrollably. These episodes last less than a minute, and the patient appears confused after that. Non-contrast head CT scan is within normal limits, and his labs do not reveal any abnormalities. He is diagnosed with generalized tonic-clonic seizures and initiated on lamotrigine. In addition to inhibiting voltage-gated sodium channels, which other mechanism of action does this medication carry that helps to control seizures?

choices.text: Decrease glutamate release in the central nervous system
Increase glutamate release in the central nervous system
Directly bind to and stimulate the GABA-A receptor

questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure and was started on lamotrigine–an antiepileptic medication that works via two primary mechanisms: voltage-gated sodium channel blockade and inhibition of glutamate release.    

Glutamate is the major excitatory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system and is associated with an increased propensity for seizure development. When released in the synaptic cleft, glutamate opens ligand-gated ion channels and induces depolarization of the postsynaptic membrane inducing action potentials.  

Antiepileptic medications associated with decreased release of glutamate include lamotrigine and topiramate. These anticonvulsants inhibit voltage-gated sodium channels, while topiramate inhibits voltage-gated calcium channels.  



Option Analysis

✅ Decrease glutamate release in the central nervous system :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increase glutamate release in the central nervous system :
Incorrect: Glutamate is the major excitatory neurotransmitter.  Increased glutamate release in the central nervous system is associated with a lower seizure threshold. Lamotrigine decreases the release of glutamate. 
❌ Inhibit the breakdown of GABA :
Incorrect: GABA is broken down by the enzyme GABA transaminase, which is inhibited by vigabatrin and valproic acid. Lamotrigine does not inhibit this enzyme. 
❌ Inhibit the reuptake of GABA :
Incorrect: Tiagabine is an antiepileptic drug that inhibits the reuptake of GABA. Lamotrigine does not inhibit GABA reuptake.
❌ Directly bind to and stimulate the GABA-A receptor:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepines and barbiturates bind to the GABA-A receptor and stimulate it, not lamotrigine.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance because of altered mental status. Witnesses report that he collapsed in the grocery store and developed rhythmic stiffening and jerking movements lasting two minutes. He was confused and combative when emergency services arrived. He had a similar second convulsion lasting one minute en route to the hospital. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient is drowsy and cannot be fully aroused; he opens his eyes to painful stimuli. His nares are patent. There is an abrasion on the tongue. He has no nuchal rigidity. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Sodium      138 mEq/L    
 Potassium      4.2 mEq/L    
 Chloride      95 mEq/L    
 Urine toxicology screen     Negative    
 Finger-stick glucose     58 mg/dL    
 Hemoglobin     14 g/dL    
 Platelet count     300,000/mm3

choices.text: Computerized tomography of the head without contrast

questions.solution:
This patient is in convulsive status epilepticus based on his repeated seizures without return to baseline in between. Patients presenting in convulsive status epilepticus with a point-of-care glucose level < 60 mg/dL should be given IV thiamine, then dextrose; if seizures persist, this should be followed by a benzodiazepine. A second dose of benzodiazepine may be given if seizures persist and should be followed by a bolus infusion of an antiseizure medication.       

The appropriate initial response to a patient presenting in convulsive status epilepticus, defined as either a prolonged convulsions (>5 minutes) or multiple seizures without return to baseline in between, is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. Continuous vital sign monitoring with cardiac telemetry allows for assessment of level of distress. The patient may require intubation and mechanical ventilation. Intravenous (IV) access should be established immediately. After stabilization, the acute management involves identification and treatment of readily reversible causes. For instance, thiamine and then dextrose should be given for hypoglycemia, which helps decrease the risk of Wernike encephalopathy since thiamine is required for the metabolism of glucose. If seizures persist despite correcting potential reversible causes, then seizure medications for seizure cessation should be given. Patients with refractory seizures may be given multiple boluses of different antiseizure medications before moving to a continuous anesthetic infusion with electroencephalography monitoring.        

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous thiamine followed by dextrose:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Endotracheal intubation :
Incorrect: Patients like this one presenting with convulsive status epilepticus may not be able to protect their airway, requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation. This patient is breathing spontaneously with an intact airway and normal oxygen saturation; therefore, endotracheal intubation is not needed at this time. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) benzodiazepine:
Incorrect: Patients with convulsive status epilepticus, defined as multiple seizures without return to baseline in between, may be treated with IV benzodiazepines. However, this patient has a low finger stick glucose, and since hypoglycemia is a reversible cause of seizures and status epilepticus, the hypoglycemia should be managed first. 
❌ Electroencephalography (EEG):
Incorrect: EEG monitoring can be used to evaluate for non-convulsive status epilepticus or to guide use of a continuous infusion for treatment of seizures. Immediate management of adults with convulsive status epilepticus includes ABCDE assessment, a focused history and physical examination, and laboratory studies and treatment of any reversible causes of seizures. 
❌ Computerized tomography of the head without contrast:
Incorrect: While head trauma is on the differential diagnosis for a patient presenting with convulsions, after acute stabilization, immediate identification and correction of metabolic derangements, medication use or withdrawal, and intoxication should be performed prior to obtaining imaging. Any potential reversible causes of seizures should be treated.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man comes to the office due to dry cough, malaise, fatigue and arthralgias for the past month. He has also experienced unintentional weight loss over the past 3 months. He has no shortness of breath. His past medical history includes a history of chronic rhinosinusitis. He does not drink alcohol, smoke cigarettes, or use recreational drugs. He is comfortable and in no respiratory distress. Vitals are within normal limits. Pulmonary auscultation reveals occasional rhonchi and no wheezing. There are no heart murmurs, the tip of the spleen is not palpable, palpable purpura is present on the lower extremities, and no joint swelling is appreciated. Laboratory results are shown below. Urinalysis is positive for blood and protein, and urine sediment analysis reveals multiple red blood cells casts. Given the most likely underlying condition, which of the following additional features is most likely to be present? 

 Laboratory Study     Results    
 Hemoglobin     9.5 g/dL    
 Leukocytes     5,500/mm3    
 Platelets     610,000/mm3    
 Creatinine     2.1 mg/dL    
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)     80 mm/hr
questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical presentation is consistent with systemic vasculitis. He has a history of chronic rhinosinusitis, with a recent onset of fatigue and weight loss, cough, and arthralgias. He has rhonchi, palpable purpura, elevated inflammatory markers, and lab work consistent with anemia, and renal involvement, making granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) the most likely diagnosis. Patients with GPA frequently have ear, nose, and throat involvement, and saddle nose deformity can be seen due to bone and cartilage destruction from granulomatous inflammation and necrosis.        

GPA is a small-vessel vasculitis that can affect almost any tissue and can present similarly to microscopic polyangiitis (MPA). In addition to nonspecific constitutional symptoms, renal involvement, and lower respiratory involvement, patients with GPA often present with ear, nose, and throat signs and symptoms, such as recurrent sinus infections, nasal congestion, epistaxis, nasal crusting, and saddle nose deformity. Chest imaging showing lung nodules and positive PR3-ANCA would further support the diagnosis.        

Vasculitides share many similar features, including nonspecific systemic symptoms like fever, weight loss, and fatigue. Certain findings can aid in differentiating the specific type of vasculitis, as detailed in the chart below.    



Option Analysis

❌ Jaw claudication:
Incorrect: Jaw claudication is suggestive of giant cell arteritis (GCA) which is a large-vessel vasculitis that typically does not occur in patients under 50 years of age.
❌ Limb claudication:
Incorrect: Limb claudication is seen with Takayasu arteritis. It is not seen in patients with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), which is the most likely diagnosis. 
❌ New diagnosis of severe asthma:
Incorrect: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss or allergic granulomatosis) is a vasculitis that is associated with severe adult-onset asthma, and prominent peripheral blood eosinophilia, and vasculitis. Asthma is always present in the prodromal phase of the disease. This patient with fatigue and unintentional weight loss, arthralgias, chronic sinusitis, and pulmonary and renal involvement most likely has granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) which is not associated with asthma. 
✅ Saddle nose deformity:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Digital ulcers and gangrene:
Incorrect: Digital ulcerations and gangrene are characteristic of thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger disease), which is a medium-vessel vasculitis that is strongly associated with smoking. It is not typically seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with systemic symptoms, arthralgias, chronic sinusitis, and pulmonary and renal involvement.

questions.text:
A 3-day-old newborn female in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) is being evaluated for hypotonia and decreased spontaneous movements. She was born at 28 weeks' gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery for preterm labor and required immediate resuscitation and intubation. There was no history of maternal fever, and maternal labs are within normal limits. There has been no fever, vomiting, or bloody stools. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F) and stable, pulse is 168/min, respirations are 38/min, blood pressure is 52/28 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 98%. On physical exam, the patient is intubated, hypotonic and has decreased spontaneous movements. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. Heart sounds are normal, and there is no murmur. Lungs are clear with equal air entry bilaterally. Abdominal exam is unremarkable. Nasogastric tube and umbilical lines are in place. The newborn is tolerating appropriate volumes of nasogastric and parenteral nutrition. Labs are shown below. Which of the following findings would confirm the most likely diagnosis?
 
 Laboratory value     Results     
 Hemoglobin      12 g/dL    
 Hematocrit      36%    
 White blood cells     8,000 /mm3    
 Platelets      130,000/mm3    
 Sodium      136 mEq/L    
 Potassium      4.8 mEq/L    
 PH     7.35    
 PCO2     39 mmHg    
 Bicarbonate (HCO3)     22 mEq/L

choices.text: Portal venous gas on abdominal radiograph
Blood in the germinal matrix on cranial ultrasound

questions.solution:
This preterm neonate was born at 28 weeks’ gestation and is hypotonic with decreased spontaneous movements several days after delivery. In the setting of prematurity and mechanical ventilation, these findings are consistent with intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH). Blood in the germinal matrix on cranial ultrasound would confirm the diagnosis of intraventricular hemorrhage.

Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) can occur in premature and exceptionally low birth weight infants due to blood vessel fragility and instability of cerebral blood flow within the highly vascular germinal matrix of premature infants’ brains. Other risk factors for IVH besides prematurity include cardiopulmonary resuscitation, mechanical ventilation, and neonatal transport. Intraventricular hemorrhages can have severe complications, including posthemorrhagic ventricular dilatation and hydrocephalus.

Most infants with IVH are asymptomatic. Although uncommon, neonates with severe intracranial bleeding may present with rapid-onset apnea, seizures, flaccid weakness, decreased alertness, and a bulging fontanelle. IVH is diagnosed with cranial ultrasound, which is routinely performed between 7 and 14 days of life for all infants born before 30 weeks of gestation. The severity of the germinal matrix and intraventricular hemorrhage is based on the location and extent of the bleed, the presence of ventricular dilatation, and extension into the periventricular white matter. Management should focus on stabilizing the patient, maintaining circulation, treating seizures, and correcting any apparent coagulation abnormalities

Option Analysis

❌ Portal venous gas on abdominal radiograph:
Incorrect: Portal venous gas on abdominal radiograph confirms necrotizing enterocolitis. Patients typically present with feeding intolerance and abdominal distention, which this patient does not have. This premature infant with hypotonia and decreased spontaneous movements most likely has an intraventricular hemorrhage (IHV). Cranial ultrasound showing blood in the germinal matrix will confirm the diagnosis of IVH.
✅ Blood in the germinal matrix on cranial ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Low blood glucose:
Incorrect: Premature infants are at risk for hypoglycemia, which often presents as jitteriness, irritability, tachypnea, and pallor. This patient is receiving nasogastric and parental nutrition, and electrolytes are appropriate for age, making hypoglycemia unlikely. Intraventricular hemorrhage is the most probable cause of hypotonia and decreased spontaneous movements in this patient.
❌ Abnormal electroencephalogram (EEG) :
Incorrect: The most likely underlying cause of the patient’s symptoms (hypotonia and decreased spontaneous movements) is an intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), which can be confirmed with the finding of blood in the germinal matrix on cranial ultrasound. IVH is not diagnosed with an EEG.
❌ Positive blood culture:
Incorrect: Positive blood culture would confirm neonatal sepsis, which typically presents with temperature instability, tachycardia, and hypotension. Given this patient’s clinical findings and normal white blood cell count, intraventricular hemorrhage is the most likely diagnosis, and cranial ultrasound showing blood in the germinal matrix would confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 73-year-old person comes to a neurology clinic to establish care after a recent hospitalization for stroke. The patient sustained acute right-sided hemiparesis and was found to have a large ischemic stroke involving the left middle cerebral artery. The patient did not receive fibrinolytic therapy due to presenting eight hours following symptom onset. Muscle strength significantly improved after physical therapy. However, the patient reports that they are now unable to differentiate between the fingers in their right hand, and they are now unable to write. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows motor strength is 4/5 on the right side. When asked to elevate the left hand, the patient elevates the right hand. The patient is unable to solve a simple mathematical problem. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with inability to recognize individual fingers (finger agnosia), left-right disorientation, and acalculia (inability to solve simple math); they most likely have Gerstmann syndrome. 

The angular gyrus refers to an area located in the inferior parietal lobe of the dominant hemisphere that integrates visual, acoustic, and somatosensory information necessary for problem solving (in particular, speech and number processing). It is supplied by the angular and posterior parietal arteries, which are branches of the middle cerebral artery (MCA). Occlusion of these arteries in the dominant hemisphere can result in Gerstmann Syndrome (as in this patient), or, in rare cases, the syndrome can result from a traumatic brain injury or a brain tumor in the same region. Clinical manifestations include finger agnosia, left-right disorientation, acalculia, agraphia (inability to write), and alexia (inability to read).  



Option Analysis

❌ Kluver-Bucy syndrome:
Incorrect: Kluver-Bucy syndrome results from bilateral lesions of the amygdala and surrounding cortex of the temporal lobe. Affected patients present with hypersexuality, hyperphagia, and an urge for exploring objects by mouth (hyperorality). Some patients exhibit visual agnosia, or psychic blindness, and personality changes, like passivity or docility.  
❌ Hemispatial neglect syndrome:
Incorrect: Hemispatial neglect syndrome is caused by a lesion in the inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere. Clinical features associated with this syndrome include spatial neglect of the contralateral body. Examples include construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, the individual only draws the right half of the clock) and dressing apraxia (the individual only dresses half of their body). 
✅ Gerstmann syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Frontal lobe syndrome:
Incorrect: Frontal lobe syndrome occurs as a result of damage to the prefrontal cortex. This condition presents with disinhibition and deficits in concentration, judgment, and orientation. Early behavioral changes include socially inappropriate behavior, apathy, and compulsive behavior.
❌ Damage to the corpus callosum:
Incorrect: The corpus callosum transfers information between the cerebral hemispheres. Damage to the corpus callosum results in transcortical apraxia, wherein the patient is unable to execute learned motor movement using the side of the body supplied by the nondominant hemisphere.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man was brought to the emergency department for evaluation of a severe headache for the past hour. The patient has never had a similar episode in the past. His past medical history includes end-stage renal disease due to autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 172/104 mmHg. Non-contrast CT-brain demonstrates hyperlucent density within the subarachnoid space. The patient is subsequently admitted to the neuro-critical care unit for further monitoring. Four days following the incident, the patient’s nurse notes new onset left-sided hemiplegia and worsening somnolence. Administration of which of the following medication classes could have prevented this patient’s current clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) secondary to rupture of a berry aneurysm. In SAH, the bleeding occurs between the arachnoid and pia mater, most commonly in the anterior half of the circle of Willis at bifurcations between the anterior communicating artery and the anterior cerebral artery. Genetic disorders such as ADPKD, Marfan syndrome, and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome are associated with impaired collagen synthesis and predispose individuals to developing saccular aneurysms.

After the initial insult, the patient develops focal neurologic deficits and lethargy, consistent with delayed cerebral ischemia (DCI). DCI occurs in ⅓ of patients with aneurysmal SAH, typically between 4 to 14 days following symptom onset. The pathophysiology of DCI is poorly understood, but it is postulated to be due to post-traumatic vasospasm with subsequent ischemia to surrounding brain tissue. To mitigate these effects, patients with SAH are frequently prescribed calcium channel blockers (e.g. nimodipine) to relax the smooth muscle found within cerebral vasculature. 

Option Analysis

❌ Alpha-1 agonist:
Incorrect: Augmenting blood pressure with vasopressors is the cornerstone of first-line therapy for delayed cerebral ischemia. Norepinephrine, dopamine, and phenylephrine can all be used to improve cerebral blood flow and/or cerebral oxygenation, resulting in clinical improvement of the neurological deficit in many patients. However, these medications would not have prevented this patient’s current clinical condition.
❌ Benzodiazepine:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepine medications such as lorazepam can help to mitigate active seizure activity following subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH); however, routine administration of benzodiazepines is not recommended after SAH unless clinically warranted.
✅ Calcium channel blocker:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction is common after subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH); however, routine administration of glucocorticoids is not recommended after SAH.
❌ Nonselective beta-blocker:
Incorrect: Blood pressure control is necessary in patients presenting with subarachnoid hemorrhage, and current guidelines suggest the goal is to maintain systolic blood pressure (SBP) <160 mmHg or mean arterial pressure (MAP) <110 mmHg. Beta-blockers, however, would not have prevented this patient’s current condition.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after he was found unresponsive at home. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes and hypertension. The patient's last medication refill was almost two years ago. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 109/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 240/190 mm Hg. The patient has extensor posturing and pinpoint pupils. A CT scan of the head without contrast is shown below.  


Reproduced from Radiopedia  
Despite resuscitative measures, the patient dies several hours later. Damage to which of the following structures is most associated with the depressed level of consciousness observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a hypertensive hemorrhage in the posterior rostral pons, a portion of the brainstem that houses the reticular activating system (RAS).

The RAS is a network of neurons originating in the tegmentum of the upper pons and midbrain that is especially important in maintaining consciousness. The RAS sends fibers towards the cerebral cortex, ensuring wakefulness and the ability to recognize and react to stimuli. Lesions of the tegmentum of the upper pons and midbrain RAS reduce the level of arousal and consciousness, leading to lethargy, stupor, and coma.  

Option Analysis

❌ Rostral ventral medulla  :
Incorrect: The rostral ventromedial medulla refers to a group of neurons located close to the midline of the medulla oblongata. This region transmits both descending inhibitory and excitatory fibers to dorsal horn spinal cord neurons, which are characterized by their response to nociceptive inputs.  
✅ Reticular activating system:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Internal capsule:
Incorrect: Damage to the internal capsule presents with contralateral hemiparesis, dysarthria, and contralateral hemisensory loss. The internal capsule is often affected in patients with putaminal hemorrhages. This patient’s CT scan is suggestive of a pontine hemorrhage.  
❌ Posterior pituitary  :
Incorrect: The posterior pituitary releases oxytocin and vasopressin produced by the hypothalamus. These hormones do not play a role in maintaining consciousness.  
❌ Basal ganglia  :
Incorrect: The “basal ganglia” refers to a group of subcortical nuclei responsible for motor control, motor learning, executive and behavioral function, as well as emotional regulation. It is not involved in maintaining consciousness.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presents to the emergency department following a 30-minute episode of left hand weakness. During the episode, he was unable to pick up any object at home. He denies any difficulty in ambulation or speaking during the episode. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension and a 25-pack-year smoking history. He drinks 1-2 beers on the weekend. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 138/88 mmHg. BMI is 21 kg/m2. He is alert and oriented, and his speech is fluent and clear. Motor strength is normal in all extremities, and there are no focal deficits. Noncontrast head CT shows no abnormalities. Electrocardiogram demonstrates normal sinus rhythm. Which of the following interventions is most appropriate for long-term risk mitigation given this patient's clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with resolved neurological deficits, and likely suffered a transient ischemic attack (TIA). Up to 80% of strokes following a TIA are preventable; therefore, early diagnosis and treatment are critical for risk mitigation.

A TIA is managed via calculation of the risk of suffering a subsequent stroke by taking into account the patient’s age, blood pressure, clinical findings, duration of the TIA, and presence of associated risk factors. If the individual is deemed high risk, further hospitalization for advanced testing is appropriate. In addition, risk factor modification is appropriate for all patients with TIA, including blood pressure reduction, statins, antiplatelet therapy, lifestyle modification, and smoking cessation.

Regardless of risk factors, all patients with ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack should be prescribed antiplatelet therapy, preferably aspirin. If the patient was previously on daily aspirin therapy, the addition of clopidogrel is the most appropriate next step in management. Additionally, initiation of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) lowering therapy with a statin, independent of the baseline LDL-C, is appropriate as well.    

Option Analysis

❌ Administration of alteplase:
Incorrect: Alteplase is first-line therapy for an ischemic stroke with persistent neurologic deficits, provided that treatment is initiated within 4.5 hours of symptom onset and the patient does not meet any strict exclusion criteria (e.g., history of gastrointestinal bleeding, history of head trauma). This patient no longer has any neurologic deficits (he likely suffered from a TIA), making him ineligible for alteplase treatment.
✅ Initiation of aspirin and atorvastatin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Initiation of warfarin:
Incorrect: Long-term anticoagulation with warfarin may be beneficial for stroke prevention in patients with atrial fibrillation. This patient’s ECG is normal.
❌ Reduction of alcohol consumption:
Incorrect: Excessive alcohol consumption can increase the risk of various morbidities; however, this patient consumes a minimal amount of alcohol.
❌ Weight loss:
Incorrect: Weight loss is one of the most effective methods in lowering blood pressure and therefore in reducing the risk of a future stroke; however, this patient has a healthy BMI.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of left-sided numbness and unsteady gait. The patient was having dinner with family one hour ago when she suddenly developed numbness in the left side of her body and could no longer sense the temperature of her food. Past medical history includes diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient takes metformin, glipizide, amlodipine, losartan, and atorvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 190/100 mmHg. Neurological examination demonstrates deficits in touch, two-point discrimination, pain, and temperature on the left side of the body and face. Motor strength and speech are normal. Romberg sign is positive. An ischemic stroke involving which of the following areas of the brain is the most likely cause of her clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden-onset, unilateral sensory deficits (touch, two-point discrimination, pain, and temperature) without cortical signs or motor deficits. A positive Romberg test suggests an additional deficit in proprioception. This presentation is suggestive of a pure sensory stroke involving the thalamic nuclei.  

The thalamus is a component of the diencephalon that lies on either side of the third ventricle and serves as the site of integration of somatosensory information. The thalamic nuclei include the ventral posteromedial nucleus (VPM) and the ventral posterolateral nucleus (VPL). The former receives afferent neuronal fibers from the trigeminal lemniscus and the gustatory pathway, while the latter receives afferent information from the dorsal column pathway (medial and lateral lemniscus) and from the lateral spinothalamic tract. These pathways carry sensory information regarding vibration, proprioception, pressure, pain, taste, light touch, and temperature. Efferent neuronal fibers from these nuclei terminate in the primary somatosensory cortex.  

Clinical manifestations of an ischemic thalamic stroke include loss of touch, pain, temperature, vibration, proprioception, and tactile discrimination over the contralateral half of the body (including sensory loss over the contralateral side of the face without motor deficits or cortical signs). Thalamic lesions are frequently the result of a lacunar stroke (small vessel microatheroma or lipohyalinosis). Risk factors for these lesions include hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia (all of which are present in this patient).  



Option Analysis

❌ Hypothalamus:
Incorrect: The hypothalamus is the site of regulation of temperature, hunger, satiety, endocrine functions, circadian rhythm, emotion, behavior, and sexual drive. It is not involved in relaying somatosensory information.
✅ Thalamus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Posterior limb of internal capsule:
Incorrect: Internal capsule is a subcortical white matter structure that relays sensory-motor information from the brainstem and contralateral body to the brain. Strokes involving the posterior limb of the internal capsule present with pure motor or mixed sensory-motor deficits, as opposed to pure sensory deficits. 
❌ Brainstem:
Incorrect: Stroke syndromes involving the brainstem are accompanied by signs and symptoms of autonomic, corticospinal (motor), and/or cranial nerve(s) involvement. Pure sensory deficits are not usually seen.
❌ Cerebral cortex:
Incorrect: Cortical strokes involving the somatosensory areas of the brain can be differentiated from thalamic strokes by the presence of cortical symptoms, which include aphasia, neglect, and behavioral changes.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner due to dizziness, difficulty walking, and severe headache for two hours. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type II diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), blood pressure is 182/106 mmHg, pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 20/min. Neurologic examination demonstrates right-sided dysmetria on finger-to-nose testing and right-sided dysrhythmia with rapid finger tapping. The patient appears to have difficulty with balance and a propensity to fall to the right side. Motor strength and sensation are symmetric and preserved bilaterally, and no speech deficits are apparent. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic location of this patient’s brain lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has a lateral cerebellar hemisphere lesion resulting in ipsilateral deficits (imbalance and falling toward the side of the lesion), limb ataxia, and intention tremor.

Lateral lesions of the cerebellum affect the cortex of the cerebellar hemispheres and deep cerebellar nuclei, including the dentate, emboliform, and globose nuclei. Cerebellar efferent fibers first cross to the contralateral side and the ipsilateral side. Together, these structures assist in planning and programming movements that influence the proximal flexor muscles of the upper extremities.

Clinically, lateral cerebellar lesions result in ipsilateral limb ataxia (loss of coordination of the limb on the same side as the lesion), which can lead to intention tremor (involuntary, trembling movements that occur with voluntary movements), dysmetria (loss of coordination that presents as the overshoot or undershoot of the intended position of the extremities), dysdiadochokinesia (inability to perform fast alternating movements), decreased muscle tone of the extremities and loss of balance, with a tendency to fall towards the side of the lesion.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cerebellar vermis  :
Incorrect: Lesions that affect midline structures of the cerebellum, such as the vermis or the flocculonodular lobe, cause problems such as truncal ataxia, cerebellar gait, and the proximal muscle groups. This patient’s intention tremor and limb ataxia suggest an alternative structure.  
✅ Lateral cerebellar hemisphere  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lateral medulla  :
Incorrect: A lateral medullary infarct can occur due to occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar or vertebral artery. Patients typically present with loss of pain and temperature of the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, ipsilateral bulbar muscle weakness, vestibulocerebellar impairment, and Horner syndrome.  
❌ Medial mid-pons  :
Incorrect: A medial mid-pontine infarction presents with contralateral ataxia and hemiparesis of the face, trunk, and limbs. There is a variable loss of contralateral tactile and position sense. This patient’s intention tremor and ipsilateral limb ataxia with preserved sensations suggest an alternative structure.  
❌ Medial medulla  :
Incorrect: Medial medullary syndrome presents with contralateral paralysis of the arm and leg and tongue deviation towards the lesion.

questions.text: A 68-year-old, right-handed man is brought to the emergency department to evaluate sudden onset weakness. The patient awoke with left-hand clumsiness that rapidly progressed to left-sided weakness, affecting the left arm more than the left leg. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. The patient’s last refill of medications was one year ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 200/110 mm Hg. On physical examination, the patient has slurred speech, left-sided facial weakness sparing the forehead, 2/5 muscle strength in the left upper limb, and 4/5 muscle strength in the left lower limb. Right-sided strength and sensation are normal. A right-sided infarct localized to the paramedian pontine base is seen on MRI. Which of the following additional findings will likely be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has an infarct of the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF), which is located in the pons and supplied by the paramedian branches of the basilar artery.

The PPRF is the subcortical lateral gaze center, which normally receives input from the contralateral frontal eye field to stimulate the lateral rectus muscle of the ipsilateral eye via the ipsilateral abducens nucleus. This signal is also transmitted to the medial longitudinal fasciculus of the contralateral oculomotor nuclei to stimulate the medial rectus muscle of the contralateral eye. Together, these signals result in both eyes' simultaneous, conjugate movement towards the left or the right.

Common causes of lesions to the PPRF include ischemic or hemorrhagic strokes of the paramedian branches of the basilar artery. When these lesions occur, both eyes deviate toward the contralateral side, away from the brain lesion. On the contrary, the frontal eye field lesions produce similar symptoms where both eyes deviate but to the ipsilateral side, towards the brain lesion. For example, when the eyes deviate to the right, the lesion can either involve the left PPRF or the right frontal eye field.  

Option Analysis

❌ Bitemporal hemianopia:
Incorrect: The x-shaped optic chiasm serves as the point of partial crossing of fibers from the optic nerve. Damage to this structure results in bitemporal hemianopia. Common etiologies include pituitary tumors, craniopharyngiomas, and aneurysms of the anterior communicating artery.  
❌ Eye deviation to the right  :
Incorrect: Destructive lesions of the frontal eye field (e.g. middle cerebral artery stroke) cause the eyes to look toward the side of brain lesion (i.e. away from the side of hemiplegia). The middle cerebral artery does not supply blood to the paramedian pontine base.  
✅ Eye deviation to the left  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Contralateral hemianopia with macular sparing  :
Incorrect: Contralateral hemianopia with macular sparing is characteristic of posterior cerebral artery infarction. Other features include alexia without agraphia when the dominant hemisphere is affected.  
❌ Vertical gaze palsy  :
Incorrect: Parinaud (dorsal midbrain) syndrome is characterized by limitation of upward gaze with a downward gaze preference, bilateral eyelid lid retraction, and near-light dissociation (i.e. pupils react to accommodation but not to light). These findings often result from compression of the pretectal region of the midbrain (most likely from a pinealoma).

questions.text: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset of weakness of the right upper and right lower extremity for three hours. He does not have chest pain, shortness of breath, or leg pain. His past medical history includes recurrent infections when he lived in Mexico as a child, all of which were resolved with “home remedies.” He immigrated to the United States in his 30’s and was told by several physicians he has a cardiac murmur. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min and irregularly irregular, and blood pressure is 141/78 mmHg. The patient’s pulse oximetry is 99% on room air. He has marked weakness and sensory loss of  the right arm and right leg. There is no warmth, swelling or increased diameter of either leg. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: CT of the brain with contrast
CT of the brain without contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of sudden onset hemiplegia in the setting of an irregularly irregular heart rate, consistent with an embolic stroke secondary to atrial fibrillation. The two main types of stroke are  ischemic and hemorrhagic, with different management approaches for each. Therefore, differentiating between these two entities is the initial, primary goal, which is best accomplished with a stat  non-contrast CT scan of the brain. I  

In the case of an ischemic stroke, the primary management involves thrombolytic therapy (e.g. alteplase administration or thrombectomy) dependent on the time-course of illness. For eligible patients with acute ischemic stroke--that is 4.5 hours since symptom onset--intravenous tPA is first-line therapy. Since the administration of alteplase is time dependent, patients with concern for ischemic stroke need to be evaluated expeditiously.

In the initial evaluation of stroke, administration of intravenous contrast should be avoided to prevent the masking of blood from underlying hemorrhage--since both contrast and blood appear as white, or hyperdense lucencies on CT imaging. If a non-contrast CT brain is without evidence of hyperdense lucency, the patient may be suffering from an ischemic stroke.

Option Analysis

❌ CT of the brain with contrast:
Incorrect: Obtaining a noncontrast CT of the head to exclude hemorrhagic stroke is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient, as hemorrhagic stroke cannot be reliably distinguished from ischemic stroke on clinical grounds alone. The use of contrast would inhibit the ability to visualize underlying hemorrhage. 
✅ CT of the brain without contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Electroencephalogram:
Incorrect: An electroencephalogram (EEG) may be beneficial in patients who present with syncope or seizures. They are not, however, useful in the initial management of patients presenting with signs and symptoms of a stroke.
❌ MRI of the brain:
Incorrect: Head imaging is crucial in the initial steps of stroke management; however, CT is preferred initial imaging due to its rapidity and effectiveness at distinguishing between ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke.
❌ Transthoracic echocardiogram:
Incorrect: Transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiography can detect cardiogenic and aortic sources of cerebral embolic stroke. Utilization of these tests should be postponed until later in the hospitalization, when the patient is in a stable clinical condition.
❌ Transesophageal echocardiogram:
Incorrect: Transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiography can detect cardiogenic and aortic sources of cerebral embolic stroke. Utilization of these tests should be postponed until later in the hospitalization, when the patient is in a stable clinical condition.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the clinic for evaluation of memory problems. The patient has become increasingly forgetful and has trouble remembering recent events, but memory of remote events remains intact. The patient is able to cook for himself and has no trouble getting around the neighborhood. The patient does not have depressive symptoms. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia for which amlodipine, valsartan, metformin, insulin and atorvastatin are prescribed. The patient has been smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for 35 years. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 155/90 mmHg. Mental status examination is significant for anterograde amnesia. Pathologic involvement of which of the following areas of the brain is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

choices.text: Inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere

questions.solution:
This patient presents with isolated anterograde amnesia (difficulty remembering recent events) without dysfunction in performing activities of daily living; he has most likely suffered damage to the hippocampus. Past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension, active smoking, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia puts this patient at risk of having significant atherosclerotic disease.  

The hippocampus serves as a component of the limbic system, which is involved in the formation and retrieval of recent memories and in the conversion of recent memory to long-term memory. The hippocampus receives its blood supply from the terminal branches of the anterior choroidal artery and posterior cerebral artery and is in a watershed area, making it particularly susceptible to ischemic damage. Injury to the hippocampus results in anterograde amnesia (the inability to form new memories) with preservation of remote past memories.  



Option Analysis

❌ Nucleus basalis:
Incorrect: The nucleus basalis is involved in the production of acetylcholine for the cerebral cortex. Decreased production of acetylcholine is believed to play a significant role in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer disease. This patient presents with isolated memory loss without dysfunction in activities of daily living and is therefore less likely to have Alzheimer dementia.
❌ Ventral tegmentum:
Incorrect: The ventral tegmentum provides dopaminergic input, and decreased activity can be associated with Parkinson disease.
❌ Raphe nucleus:
Incorrect: The raphe nucleus provides serotonergic input, and decreased activity of this region of the brain is sometimes associated with depression.
✅ Hippocampus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere:
Incorrect: Hemispatial neglect syndrome is caused by a lesion to the inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere. It results in spatial neglect of the contralateral side of the body. Examples include construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, the individual only draws the right half of the clock) and dressing apraxia (the individual only dresses half of their body).

questions.text: A 72-year-old right-handed person is brought to the clinic to establish care. The patient was recently discharged from the hospital where they were admitted for the management of a stroke. The patient initially presented with left-sided hemiparesis and was found to have a large ischemic stroke involving the right middle cerebral artery. The patient did not receive fibrinolytic therapy as they presented outside of the administration window. The patient participated in physical therapy during hospitalization and reports that muscle strength has improved significantly. The patient reports that they feel like they are coming back to their baseline. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows motor strength of 4/5 on the left side. Dress and appearance on the left side of their body appears unkempt. When asked to draw a clock and copy a box and a flower, their drawings appear as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient who presents with construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, they only draw the right half of the clock) and dressing apraxia (inattention to the left side of the body) most likely has spatial neglect of the contralateral side of the body. This patient also exhibits anosognosia (unawareness of neural defect). Together, these features suit a diagnosis of hemispatial neglect syndrome.

Hemispatial neglect syndrome results from injury to the inferior parietal lobe in the non-dominant hemisphere. This area houses the somatosensory association area and is supplied by the angular and posterior parietal arteries, which are branches of the middle cerebral artery (MCA). Injury to this area ultimately results in a patient who is unable to integrate somatic and visual inputs and cannot appreciate an image on the opposite side of the body.  

Clinical manifestations include spatial neglect of the contralateral side of the body and anosognosia (individual is unaware of neural defect). Affected individuals may fail to shave, wash, and dress the contralateral half of their bodies. When asked to draw a clock, the patient's drawing might only show numbers on one side of the clock or all 12 numbers might be on one half with the other half distorted (construction apraxia).  

Option Analysis

❌ Kluver-Bucy syndrome:
Incorrect: Kluver-Bucy syndrome results from bilateral lesions of the amygdala and surrounding cortex of the temporal lobe. Affected patients present with hypersexuality, hyperphagia, and an urge for exploring objects by mouth (hyperorality). Some patients exhibit visual agnosia, or psychic blindness, and personality changes, like passivity or docility.
✅ Hemispatial neglect syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Gerstmann syndrome:
Incorrect: Gerstmann syndrome is a dominant hemispheric stroke syndrome that usually results from ischemic injury to the angular gyrus within the parietal lobe. Symptoms include finger agnosia, left-right disorientation, acalculia, agraphia, and alexia.
❌ Frontal lobe syndrome:
Incorrect: Frontal lobe syndrome occurs as a result of damage to the prefrontal cortex. This condition presents with disinhibition and deficits in concentration, judgment, and orientation. Early behavioral changes include socially inappropriate behavior, apathy, and compulsive behavior.
❌ Damage to the corpus callosum:
Incorrect: The corpus callosum transfers information between the cerebral hemispheres. Damage to the corpus callosum results in transcortical apraxia, wherein the patient is unable to execute learned motor movement using the side of the body supplied by the nondominant hemisphere.

questions.text: A 85-year-old left-handed woman is brought to the emergency department with complaints of sudden involuntary body movements. The patient states that she is having a hard time controlling movements of her right leg. Symptoms started a few hours ago. Past medical history is notable for diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a myocardial infarction five years ago. The patient takes metformin, insulin, amlodipine, valsartan, atorvastatin, and aspirin. The patient smokes one to two cigarettes per day. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 160/93 mmHg. Physical examination shows intermittent wide flinging movements of the patient’s proximal right arm and leg. Damage to which of the following parts of the brain is the most likely cause of these abnormal body movements?
questions.solution:
Hemiballismus is a form of  involuntary movement associated with diseases afflicting the subthalamic nuclei. These movements are typically unilateral, irregular, and of large amplitude (violent flinging movement of limbs) that become more prominent with action. A lacunar stroke involving penetrating branches of a large cerebral artery supplying the subthalamus is the most common etiology of hemiballismus. Risk factors for lacunar strokes include hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. 

The basal ganglia consists of gray matter masses within the cerebral hemispheres. These include the caudate, putamen, globus pallidus, and amygdaloid nucleus. The subthalamic nuclei, substantia nigra, and the red nucleus are structures functionally related to the basal ganglia. Physiologically, the subthalamic nucleus sends excitatory signals to the globus pallidus that, in turn, inhibits the thalamus and serves as an important modulator of basal ganglia output to regulate movement.  



Option Analysis

✅ Left subthalamic nucleus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Right subthalamic nucleus:
Incorrect: Injury to the right subthalamic nucleus presents with left-sided hemiballismus.
❌ Hippocampus:
Incorrect: The primary role of the hippocampus is the formation and retrieval of recent memories. Damage to this area results in anterograde amnesia.
❌ Inferior left parietal lobe:
Incorrect: Hemispatial neglect syndrome results from a lesion in the inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere. Clinical features associated with this syndrome include spatial neglect of the contralateral body. Examples include construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, the individual only draws the right half of the clock) and dressing apraxia (the individual only dresses half of their body).
❌ Bilateral amygdala:
Incorrect: Kluver-Bucy syndrome results from bilateral lesions of the amygdala and surrounding cortex of the temporal lobe. Affected patients present with hypersexuality, hyperphagia, and an urge for exploring objects by mouth (hyperorality). Some patients exhibit visual agnosia, or psychic blindness, and personality changes, like passivity or docility.

questions.text: A 75-year-old right-handed woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of right-sided weakness. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes, for which the patient takes amlodipine, chlorthalidone, and insulin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 180/99 mmHg. On examination, right upper and lower extremity motor strength is 1/5. The patient has difficulty answering questions and appears to be frustrated by this inability to communicate. The patient is able to speak a few words, but the speech is non-fluent. She is able to comprehend 2-step instructions but is unable to repeat phrases. Which of the following best describes the type of aphasia observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with difficulty answering questions and frustration driven by their inability to communicate (expressive aphasia). The patient is able to speak a few words, but speech is non-fluent. The patient is able to comprehend 2-step instructions; however, they are unable to repeat phrases, making Broca aphasia the most likely cause of the language impairment.  

Broca’s area is located in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere. Efferent pathways from Broca’s area connect to the muscles of the larynx, mouth, tongue, soft palate, and respiratory muscles to formulate speech. Broca aphasia most commonly results from an ischemic stroke secondary to anterior MCA branch occlusion. Other etiologies include trauma, tumors, and neurodegenerative disease. Typical clinical features include non-fluent, sparse speech as well as agrammatism, intact comprehension, and impaired repetition. Hemiparesis (as in this patient) and oral apraxia may occur due to ischemia sustained to the adjacent motor and supplementary areas.  



Option Analysis

❌ Transcortical sensory aphasia:
Incorrect: Transcortical sensory aphasia results from insults to the inferior temporal lobe of the dominant hemisphere. Clinical presentation includes fluent speech with intact ability to repeat but poor comprehension.  
❌ Global aphasia:
Incorrect: Global aphasia results from damage to the arcuate fasciculus, Broca’s area, and Wernicke’s area. Clinical presentation includes non-fluent speech, poor comprehension, and impaired repetition.
❌ Conduction aphasia:
Incorrect: Conduction aphasia results from a lesion involving the arcuate fasciculus. The arcuate fasciculus is the bundle of nerve fibers between Broca’s and Wernicke’s area. Clinical presentation includes fluent speech and preserved comprehension with impaired repetition. Speech often contains frequent phonemic errors.
❌ Wernicke aphasia:
