Incorrect: Wernicke’s area is involved in processing and understanding of written and spoken language. It is supplied by the posterior MCA branch and located within the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere. Damage to Wernicke’s area manifests with fluent speech and poor comprehension with impaired repetition. Speech sounds voluminous but without meaning, and the patient often appears unaware of the deficit. A right superior visual field defect may be present as well.
✅ Broca aphasia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter for evaluation of  sudden-onset weakness in the left side of her body that began two hours ago. The patient does not have chest pain, shortness of breath, or leg pain. Her past medical history includes hypertension and a 35-pack-year smoking history. She does not take anticoagulants, have any recent surgeries, or have a history of gastrointestinal bleeding. Vital signs are temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 81/min and regular, and blood pressure is 166/104 mmHg. She has marked weakness and sensory loss in the left arm and left leg. Non-contrast CT-brain is without evidence of hemorrhage or mass effect. Which of the following is the next best step in managing this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient suffered from an ischemic stroke, as suggested by the focal neurologic deficits and corroborating imaging without hemorrhage. For eligible patients with acute ischemic stroke, intravenous alteplase (tissue plasminogen activator, also known as tPA) is first-line therapy, provided that treatment is initiated within 4.5 hours of symptom onset. Since the benefit of alteplase is time dependent (“time is brain”), it is critical to initiate therapy in eligible patients expeditiously.

If CT imaging identifies hemorrhagic stroke, thrombolysis should be avoided. In addition, patients who present 4.5 hours after initial symptoms have an increased risk of developing hemorrhagic conversion from ischemia, thus further contraindicating tPA administration. Thrombolysis should also be avoided in patients with increased risk of hemorrhage, including active or recent anticoagulation, gastrointestinal hemorrhage in the past 21 days, or a history of head trauma within the past three months. 

Option Analysis

❌ Administration of aspirin and atorvastatin:
Incorrect: Aspirin and atorvastatin are used for primary and secondary prevention of ischemic strokes. Administration of aspirin within 48 hours of stroke onset may help reduce clot propagation and stroke recurrence. However, aspirin and other antithrombotic agents should not be given alone or in combination for the first 24 hours following treatment with intravenous tPA.
❌ Clopidogrel:
Incorrect: For patients with high-risk transient ischemic attack or minor ischemic stroke, dual antiplatelet treatment (DAPT) using aspirin and clopidogrel is recommended. However, aspirin and other antithrombotic agents should not be given alone or in combination for the first 24 hours following treatment with intravenous tPA.
❌ Heparin:
Incorrect: Heparin is avoided in the early stages of ischemic stroke due to minimal benefit and the increased risk of intracranial bleeding.
✅ Recombinant tissue plasminogen activator:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Supportive care:
Incorrect: Supportive care may be appropriate in patients who present with a hemorrhagic stroke or patients who present outside of the tPA administration window. This patient is a candidate for tPA.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following sudden onset, right-sided weakness. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and coronary artery disease. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 83/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 156/90 mmHg. Neurological examination demonstrates flaccid paralysis of the right upper and lower extremities, tongue deviation to the left, slurred speech, hyperreflexic deep tendon reflexes on the right, as well as decreased right-sided proprioception. Sensation is intact and the patient is oriented to person, place, and time. Which of the following anatomic areas of the brain is most likely affected given this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with complete upper and lower limb paralysis, decreased proprioception, and deviation of the tongue with protrusion, suggestive of medial medullary syndrome. This condition often arises secondary to infarction of the paramedian branches of the anterior spinal artery.  

The anterior spinal artery supplies the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord and lower medulla at the midline. The vessel lies in the anterior median fissure of the spinal cord with both penetrating and circumferential branches. Clinical features of medial medullary ischemia include:  

  • Contralateral hemiparesis due to involvement of the lateral corticospinal tract. 
  • Sensory symptoms related to ischemia of the medial lemniscus include decreased contralateral proprioception and pressure vibratory sensation. 
  • Ipsilateral tongue paralysis is the least common but most topographically localizing sign of medial medullary infarction and is due to infarction of the hypoglossal nucleus. 

Option Analysis

❌ Dominant parietal lobe  :
Incorrect: Gerstmann syndrome results from damage to the angular gyrus of the dominant parietal lobe and is characterized by agraphia (inability to write), acalculia (inability to carry out mathematical calculations), finger agnosia, and left-right disorientation.  
❌ Dorsolateral medulla:
Incorrect: Ischemic injury to the dorsolateral medulla can result in Wallenberg syndrome, secondary to infarction of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. Patients typically present with loss of pain/temperature over the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, ipsilateral bulbar muscle weakness, vertigo, ipsilateral limb ataxia, and Horner syndrome.  
✅ Medial medulla:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posterior limb of internal capsule:
Incorrect: Infarction in the posterior limb of the internal capsule results in a pure motor stroke. Patients typically present with contralateral hemiparesis without sensory loss or cortical signs (e.g. aphasia). The most common etiology of a lacunar stroke is hypertension.  
❌ Dorsolateral thalamus:
Incorrect: Acute strokes of the dorsolateral thalamus typically present with contralateral hemisensory loss. Patients often develop significant pain on the side of their deficit (thalamic pain syndrome) weeks to months following the initial insult.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office due to intermittent heaviness and paresthesias of the right arm. The patient has experienced multiple episodes over the past two months, especially while playing table tennis. Each episode is associated with nausea, dizziness, and visual disturbance. The patient has not had any falls or loss of consciousness. Past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, enalapril, and atorvastatin. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes for the past forty years and drinks alcohol occasionally. Orthostatic vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates decreased radial and brachial pulses of the right upper extremity when compared to the left upper extremity. Skin over the right upper extremity feels cooler than the left. The remainder of the cardiopulmonary and neurologic exam are within normal limits. CT angiogram is performed and reveals a condition that results in reversal of blood flow through a vascular structure. Reverse blood flow through which of the following vessels is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with subclavian steal syndrome (SSS)--a constellation of signs and symptoms that arise secondary to retrograde blood flow through the ipsilateral vertebral artery or internal thoracic artery due to stenosis and/or occlusion of the subclavian artery. In this condition, the affected arm is often supplied by blood flowing in a retrograde direction down the ipsilateral vertebral artery at the expense of the vertebrobasilar circulation.  

Given this patient's vascular risk factors (i.e., hypercholesterolemia, diabetes mellitus, hypertension), an atherosclerotic occlusive plaque in the right subclavian artery is the most likely culprit of his symptoms. Reduced blood flow through the subclavian artery results in symptoms of recurrent heaviness with exertion, paresthesias, as well as decreased pulses and cooler skin.  

Over time, stenosis of the subclavian artery increases in blood flow through the contralateral vertebral artery to the basilar artery, followed by retrograde flow through the ipsilateral vertebral artery, away from the brainstem. Ultimately, this may result in presyncopal symptoms with exertion of the affected arm including lightheadedness, nausea, and blurred vision. Other etiologies of SSS include Takayasu arteritis, Giant cell arteritis, and thoracic aortic dissection.  

Option Analysis

❌ Right subclavian artery:
Incorrect: Given this patient's vascular risk factors (i.e., hypercholesterolemia, diabetes mellitus, hypertension), he most likely has an atherosclerotic occlusive plaque of the right subclavian artery. This explains the heaviness, paresthesia, decreased pulses, and cooler skin of her right arm. Blood flow is blocked rather than reversed in this vessel.  
✅ Right vertebral artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Left vertebral artery:
Incorrect: Reduced blood flow to the stenosed side is compensated for by contralateral circulation (from the left vertebral artery in this case). In this case, there is increased blood flow from the unaffected side (left) to the affected side (right) via the vertebral arteries.  
❌ Left subclavian artery:
Incorrect: Although the left subclavian artery compensates for reduced blood flow in the right subclavian artery, it is not the underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Left posterior cerebral artery  :
Incorrect: Reversed flow in the left posterior cerebral artery results in reduced perfusion to the left occipital lobe. This may result in contralateral hemianopia due to infarction of the visual cortex.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of her altered mental status, which began three hours ago. The patient is oriented only to herself. Medical history is notable for atrial fibrillation, type II diabetes mellitus, HIV infection, and recently-diagnosed histoplasmosis pneumonia. Her medications include warfarin, propranolol, metformin, and itraconazole. She declined antiretroviral treatment in the past. On arrival, the patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 137/82 mmHg, and pulse is 78/min. Physical examination reveals 5/5 strength in all extremities. However, the patient cannot complete finger-to-nose testing or rapidly alternating movements. She attempts to get up but loses balance and falls back into the stretcher. CT head is shown below. Her INR is 7.2, blood glucose is 175 mg/dL, and her HbA1c is 9.2%. Which of the following best explains this patient’s presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status and an inability to perform coordinated movements. Her CT scan confirms the presence of a hemorrhagic stroke, which likely occurred since the patient was concurrently taking warfarin and fluconazole without dose adjustments.  

Fluconazole, and other azoles, treat mycotic infections by inhibiting fungal 14-alpha-demethylase (a cytochrome p450 enzyme). Inhibition of this enzyme blocks ergosterol synthesis, which is a vital component of fungal cell membranes.     

Unfortunately, azoles can also inhibit human cytochrome p450 found in the liver. As a result, azoles can inhibit the breakdown and cause the overaccumulation of medications (e.g., warfarin, phenytoin, simvastatin) metabolized by hepatic cytochrome p450. Elevated plasma warfarin levels would manifest with an elevated INR, as in this patient's case, as well as increased risk for bleeding and hemorrhagic stroke.  

Option Analysis

❌ Accelerated formation of atherosclerotic lesions:
Incorrect: Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus can lead to the accelerated formation of atherosclerotic plaques within blood vessels, predisposing patients to ischemic stroke. However, the hyperdense lesion on the CT scan suggests a hemorrhagic stroke. Furthermore, the elevated INR raises concerns about a different cause of the patient’s stroke.  
✅ Impaired hepatic drug metabolism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Enlargement of intracranial mass:
Incorrect: An intracranial mass (e.g. tumor) in the cerebellum can cause impaired coordination. This deficit may manifest as an inability to perform tasks that require coordination on physical examination. However, intracranial masses are more likely to cause gradual, rather than abrupt, the onset of neurological symptoms.   
❌ Embolic occlusion of intracranial vessels:
Incorrect: This patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, which can lead to thrombus formation within the left atrium. If parts of the thrombus break off and travel to the brain, the patient can develop an embolic ischemic stroke. However, this patient’s CT findings are more concerning for a hemorrhagic stroke.  
❌ Noncompliance with medical therapy:
Incorrect: Medical noncompliance, such as taking more warfarin than prescribed, can cause an elevated INR and predispose individuals to hemorrhagic stroke. However, this patient is taking warfarin concurrently with fluconazole. The latter blocks cytochrome p450, thereby inhibiting hepatic drug metabolism, and would account for the elevated INR.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance for evaluation of right-sided weakness. Two hours prior to arrival, he started having difficulty forming sentences and developed numbness of the right side of his face, arm, and leg. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and he has a 25 pack-year smoking history. His medications include insulin, metformin, lisinopril, and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. On examination, he is alert but is unable to correctly state the current month or his current age. He obeys commands. He has no eye deviation but has a right facial droop, right arm and leg drift, and decreased sensation throughout the right side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 64-year-old patient with significant risk factors presents with sudden onset neurological signs and symptoms suggestive of an acute stroke. The first step in management after stabilization of the patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation and placement on continuous vital sign monitoring is to obtain a fingerstick glucose level because hypoglycemia can mimic stroke symptoms and can be easily corrected with the administration of glucose.

A plasma glucose concentration below 70 mg/dL may cause encephalopathy and dizziness; tremor; confusion; and even focal neurological symptoms, like face or limb weakness and numbness, incoordination, dysarthria, and aphasia. A careful history may reveal risk factors for hypoglycemia, such as infection, malnutrition, or the use of certain medications (i.e. combination of insulin and metformin, sulfonylureas).   If the fingerstick glucose level is normal in a patient presenting with stroke-like symptoms, evaluation should proceed with a head CT and further investigations for an underlying etiology.   

Option Analysis

✅ Fingerstick glucose level :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) :
Incorrect: Administration of IV tPA is appropriate for some patients with acute ischemic stroke, but it is contraindicated in patients with intracranial hemorrhages and neoplasms. A fingerstick glucose level and head CT should be obtained to rule out hemorrhagic stroke and confirm ischemic stroke prior to administration of tPA. 
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin is given for ischemic strokes but only after acute management is determined based on imaging and after finger glucose is first performed to rule out hypoglycemia as the cause of the neurologic findings.  
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head:
Incorrect: A head CT is an important diagnostic tool in the evaluation of patients presenting with sudden onset neurological symptoms. However, a fingerstick glucose should be obtained first to rule out hypoglycemia as it can mimic stroke symptoms and is easily corrected with administration of glucose.  
❌ Echocardiogram :
Incorrect: An echocardiogram is an important diagnostic tool to investigate for an underlying etiology for an acute ischemic stroke like atrial fibrillation. However, because hypoglycemia can mimic stroke symptoms, a fingerstick glucose level should be obtained first, especially in this patient who is on both metformin and insulin.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance for evaluation of sudden-onset left arm numbness and weakness. One hour ago, he was talking with his grandson when he developed a tingling sensation in his left hand and face. He also had left-sided facial droop and slurred speech. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Medications include metformin, lisinopril, and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 68/min and regular, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. On examination, he is alert, oriented, and follows commands. Speech is slurred without aphasia. There is a leftward partial gaze palsy and partial hemianopia. Left facial paresis, left arm and leg drift, and left-sided decreased sensation are noted. There is no ataxia or neglect. Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without contrast is unremarkable. Which of the following should be performed next?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) of the head and neck

questions.solution:
This 70-year-old man presents with sudden onset neurological symptoms suggesting an acute ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA). If an initial computerized tomography (CT) of the head does not show hemorrhage or evidence of ischemic stroke but symptoms persist and suspicion for stroke is high, CT or magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA) may reveal vessel occlusion or source of emboli as the cause of ischemic stroke.

Patients may be candidates for mechanical thrombectomy or chemical thrombolysis. Perfusion imaging may demonstrate a penumbra of surrounding viable tissue. If higher-level imaging is unremarkable, this can suggest a TIA.

TIA is defined as a transient episode of neurologic dysfunction caused by focal ischemia without acute infarction. The diagnosis of TIA with documented absence of tissue infarction on imaging is a clinical diagnosis based on a determination that the symptoms are most likely caused by brain ischemia.

When patients have a likely stroke with neurological dysfunction that is persistent, the first step is imaging, typically with CT or sometimes MRI to determine if a hemorrhage is present. If there is no evidence of hemorrhagic stroke, then the next step is to diagnose the type of ischemic stroke by distinguishing between embolic and thrombotic ischemic strokes. If the stroke is thrombotic, the next step is determining if there is large vessel and small vessel (penetrating artery or lacunar) involvement. Echocardiogram may be performed to look for AFib and a source of emboli with embolic strokes.

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) of the head and neck:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Ambulatory cardiac monitoring:
Incorrect: Ambulatory cardiac monitoring can be performed if there is high suspicion of subclinical AFib as the cause of ischemic stroke. However, magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) of the head and neck should be performed first to distinguish between thrombotic or embolic stroke once CT rules out hemorrhagic stroke and to guide management. 
❌ Echocardiogram:
Incorrect: Echocardiography may show a patent foramen ovale, abnormal wall motion, or evidence of thrombi as the cause of an embolic stroke, but it is not diagnostic of a stroke. A magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA) should be performed first to help determine if the stroke is thrombotic or embolic. 
❌ Hemoglobin A1c:
Incorrect: While poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, as evidenced by an abnormally elevated hemoglobin A1c level, is a risk factor for acute ischemic stroke, it is not the best next step in the evaluation of ischemic stroke. 
❌ Lipid panel:
Incorrect: While poorly controlled hyperlipidemia, as evidenced by an abnormally elevated lipid panel, is a risk factor for acute ischemic stroke, it is not the best next step in the evaluation of ischemic stroke.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after collapsing in the park about 30 minutes ago while walking with his daughter. His past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and tobacco use. He is not currently taking any medication. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg. Respirations are 8/min and are shallow and irregular, and his oxygen saturation is 87% on room air. On examination, the patient is awake and alert but is not speaking. He can look up and down but not side-to-side. His face appears slack bilaterally, and he has flaccid quadriplegia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without contrast
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the head without contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of a brainstem lesion, including flaccid quadriplegia, anarthria, impaired horizontal extraocular eye movements, and bilateral facial weakness. Given the acute onset of these symptoms in the setting of several untreated stroke risk factors, the leading diagnosis is a basilar artery infarct. Since this patient also shows signs of impending respiratory failure, immediate stabilization of the airway—with endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation—is indicated.

Patients with brainstem lesions may exhibit a range of findings depending on the level involved (midbrain, pons, or medulla). These manifestations may include cranial neuropathies, respiratory changes, altered levels of consciousness, motor or sensory deficits, dysautonomia, and/or cerebellar signs.

The first step in the acute management of an unstable adult patient with a brainstem lesion is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation may be necessary, and continuous monitoring of vital signs is essential, as brainstem lesions can affect the respiratory centers, reticular activating system, and sympathetic pathways. Additionally, intravenous (IV) access should be established promptly to facilitate the administration of fluids and medications, and clinicians should monitor for and manage any associated elevations in intracranial pressure.

Option Analysis

✅ Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without contrast:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of brainstem impairment – possibly from an acute stroke – which warrant neuroimaging. However, before imaging, his shallow, irregular respirations and hypoxemia must be stabilized.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the head without contrast:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of brainstem impairment – possibly from an acute stroke – which warrant neuroimaging. However, before imaging, his shallow, irregular respirations and hypoxemia must be stabilized.
❌ Intravenous (IV) tissue plasminogen activator (tPA):
Incorrect: While an acute ischemic stroke is a consideration in this case, tPA should not be given before neuroimaging. Additionally, imaging should be delayed until this patient’s airway and breathing are secured.
❌ Intravenous labetalol:
Incorrect: This patient’s blood pressure is only minimally elevated and does not warrant immediate management with labetalol. The priority is to address the patient’s respiratory compromise.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a severe headache and new-onset horizontal double vision that began this afternoon. She has no prior history of headaches. Her past medical history is noncontributory, and she takes no medication. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is in acute distress due to pain. There is ptosis of the right eye, which is deviated downward and laterally at rest. The right eye is unable to adduct or look upward. Strength and sensation are normal throughout. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Horizontal nystagmus with abduction of the left eye
Weakness of the right upper extremity
Impaired abduction of the right eye

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of impaired right extraocular eye movements, ptosis, and headache—findings suggestive of a right cranial nerve (CN) III palsy. In cases of compressive CN III palsy from a posterior communicating artery aneurysm, a unilateral dilated pupil may also be present due to involvement of the parasympathetic fibers running along the outer surface of the oculomotor nerve.
 

Patients with brainstem lesions can present with various signs depending on the level involved (midbrain, pons, or medulla). These signs may include cranial neuropathies, respiratory changes, altered levels of consciousness, motor or sensory impairment, dysautonomia, or cerebellar findings. A careful history and physical examination are essential to narrow the differential diagnosis.

For example, impairment in eye adduction is suggestive of a lesion in the midbrain, whereas impairment in eye abduction typically indicates a lesion involving the pons. In contrast, preserved extraocular movements may point toward a lesion in the medulla.  After evaluating extraocular eye movements, further assessment for ptosis, pupil involvement, limb weakness, and sensory deficits can help refine the differential diagnosis.

Option Analysis

✅ Right eye pupillary dilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Horizontal nystagmus with abduction of the left eye:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of a right cranial nerve III palsy, potentially secondary to a ruptured posterior communicating artery aneurysm given her headache. Horizontal nystagmus in the abducting (left) eye would suggest internuclear ophthalmoplegia. However, ptosis is not typically observed in that condition.
❌ Weakness of the right upper extremity:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of a right cranial nerve III palsy, potentially secondary to a ruptured posterior communicating artery aneurysm given her headache. If weakness were to be present, it would be contralateral (i.e., left-sided) due to involvement of the corticospinal tract, which decussates in the medulla oblongata.
❌ Impaired abduction of the right eye:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of a right cranial nerve III palsy, potentially secondary to a ruptured posterior communicating artery aneurysm given her headache. Impaired eye abduction, however, would be more suggestive of a cranial nerve VI palsy.
❌ Dysphagia and dysarthria:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of a right cranial nerve III palsy, potentially secondary to a ruptured posterior communicating artery aneurysm given her headache. A lesion producing dysphagia and dysarthria would more likely be associated with medullary involvement of cranial nerves IX, X, and XII rather than with an isolated cranial nerve III palsy.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by EMS after a pedestrian found the patient sitting on the ground in a park with word-finding difficulty, saying “want water now” and “park two yesterday.” The patient is unable to write when offered a pen and paper. Past medical history is unknown. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 188/98 mmHg. On exam, the patient appears anxious and frustrated, without outward signs of injury. The patient follows commands but is unable to repeat phrases. A urine drug screen and serum ethanol level are unremarkable. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Left face, arm, and leg weakness

questions.solution:
This older adult patient presents with signs of dysfunction in the left posterior inferior frontal lobe, evidenced by non-fluent speech, impaired writing, and poor repetition with preserved comprehension. These findings are consistent with Broca aphasia. Lesions in this region often produce contralateral weakness when adjacent motor or supplementary motor areas are involved.       

Cortical lesions may cause aphasia (language impairment), anopsia (visual field deficits), agnosia (inability to recognize objects), or neglect. Identifying the dominant feature aids in localizing the lesion. Broca aphasia, marked by non-fluent speech, impaired writing, and preserved comprehension, typically indicates a lesion in the dominant (usually left) posterior inferior frontal gyrus. In contrast, Wernicke aphasia, characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech, paraphasias, and poor comprehension and repetition, suggests injury to the left posterior superior temporal gyrus. Additional deficits may occur if nearby structures are affected.       

In the absence of these symptoms of cortical impairment, the differential diagnosis of subcortical lesions can be similarly narrowed by the dominant presenting symptom, including motor symptoms (either weakness or involuntary hyperkinetic movements), hemisensory loss, or cognitive/behavioral changes (memory loss, apathy, hypersexuality, hyperphagia).  

Option Analysis

✅ Right arm weakness:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Left face, arm, and leg weakness:
Incorrect: Weakness on the left side would suggest a right hemisphere lesion. However, the patient’s Broca aphasia indicates a lesion in the left hemisphere. 
❌ Impaired hearing:
Incorrect: Thisis patient presents with Broca aphasia. Hearing loss is unlikely given the preserved ability to follow commands. Wernicke aphasia, which affects auditory comprehension, may be mistaken for hearing loss, but this is not consistent with the clinical picture. 
❌ Left homonymous hemianopsia:
Incorrect: This patient presents with Broca aphasia, which localizes to the left inferior frontal lobe. Lesions in the left frontal lobe do not typically affect the visual pathways. 
❌ Dysphagia:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of Broca aphasia. Dysphagia is more often associated with brainstem or subcortical lesions. Cortical lesions in the frontal language area are unlikely to impair swallowing.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of confusion lasting for two hours. The patient was in his usual state of health when he suddenly began speaking in short, fragmented sentences. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, for which the patient does not take his prescribed medication. A motor vehicle accident two years ago resulted in a back injury. The patient consumes alcohol and smokes tobacco daily. Family history is significant for a parent with dementia. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 210/102 mmHg. On examination, the patient is alert and appears frustrated when questioned. The patient speaks in short, grammatically incorrect sentences, has significant word-finding difficulty, and is unable to write but can read. The patient cannot repeat phrases. There is drift in the right arm. Which of the following aspects of medical history most significantly increased the risk for the development of this condition in this patient?
questions.solution:
This older adult patient presents with symptoms of expressive aphasia, characterized by word-finding difficulty and non-fluent speech, but with intact comprehension. Impaired repetition points toward Broca aphasia. The acute onset, along with right-sided weakness, suggests an acute ischemic stroke. Severe, uncontrolled hypertension is the strongest modifiable risk factor in this patient.    

Patients with aphasia may experience trouble communicating, although the abnormality may sometimes be reported by caregivers and the patient may be unaware of the language impairment. A thorough physical examination can provide clues to the etiology of aphasia and should assess verbal and written language output, comprehension, and the ability to repeat phrases.        

The differential diagnosis for aphasia depends on its type, as each is associated with specific localizations within the language circuitry pathway. Aphasia is considered a cortical sign, and the assessment should include an investigation for stroke risk factors, symptoms of space-occupying lesions, or signs of dementia.    



Option Analysis

✅ Hypertension:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Alcohol use:
Incorrect: Alcohol use can contribute to stroke risk. However, this patient's severe, uncontrolled hypertension is his most significant modifiable risk factor for ischemic stroke.  
❌ Family history:
Incorrect: This patient’s expressive aphasia and right arm weakness are likely due to an acute ischemic stroke. A family history of dementia may suggest a genetic predisposition to neurodegenerative diseases, but it is not a major risk factor for stroke. A family history of cardiovascular disease or stroke would be more relevant in this case. 
❌ Trauma history:
Incorrect: Although a history of trauma from a motor vehicle collision could affect speech and motor function, this patient’s acute symptoms are more consistent with ischemic stroke. In this case, the patient’s severe, uncontrolled hypertension is the most significant risk factor for ischemic stroke. 
❌ Tobacco use:
Incorrect: Tobacco use is a known risk factor for stroke. However, in this case, severe, uncontrolled hypertension is the strongest modifiable risk factor contributing to this patient’s ischemic stroke.
